Message.Title: Intel Processors Widen Lead at Computex
Message.Msg: Intel is already two generations ahead of its competition in multi-core processor technology. The company has shipped three dimensional (3-D) Tri-Gate 22-nanometer chips since 2011, a feat that its competitors are still only promising. This week Intel is demonstrating those technologies put to work in mainstream tablets, smartphones and novel convertible devices that straddle the fence between laptop and tablet. The event takes place at Computex 2013 (June 2-8, in Taipei, Taiwan). It’s a busy time for Intel. Last week Reuters predicted Intel’s biggest mobile design win yet will be for Samsung’s forthcoming Galaxy Tab 3. Reuters says the Galaxy Tab 3 is destined to become the world’s second-best-selling table behind Apple’s iPad. Samsung and Apple both broke with tradition by choosing an inexpensive ARM Holdings’ processor for their first-generation tablets. Intel is now leveraging its ultra-low power 3-D Tri-Gate 22-nanometer chips to lure tablet makers back into the fold. For mobile devices, the biggest news may be that Intel’s Silvermount microarchitecture–3-D Tri-Gate 22-nanometer for its Atom processors–will join the Core line. This will offer lower-power, higher-performance options to its inexpensive Pentium and Celestron processor families. Silvermount leverages Intel’s 3-D Tri-Gate 22-nanometer process to offer 3-times the peak performance and 5-times lower power over the current-generation Atom processors. In addition, Silvermount processors can run both Windows 8 and Android operating systems, giving tablet and convertible makers wider software options. by R. Colin Johnson, Slashdot Media Contributing Editor

Topic.Title: Thirty Days

Message.Msg: "[Once again you throw up your opinion with nothing to support it. You don't even know what "client business" means or how it relates to overall revenues...]" Oh really, wallis? Don't you read the IDC projections for 2013? Perhaps the wave which has already started and is building momentum in client virtualization? Yes, I know, wallis, client virtualization means that Intel probably sells more server CPUs, but the ratio isn't promising, making the client loss far greater than the server win. And who wants to virtualize clients? Many of the enterprise users at the heart of Intel's client base, including the federal government. And, of course, if the server business is so great, why is IBM trying so hard to leave the room? Could it be that Intel created a low-innovation, commoditized server market that is as vulnerable to being trumped as the me-too laptop market became? I'm as thrilled as you are that Intel got the Samsung tablet design win, and I hope that the stock finally breaks $30, a level it has not achieved since... when? The unfortunate fact is that process superiority has never been enough, wallis, high-level design and big picture architecture has always been more important. So far I'm looking at the same old same old, strategy-wise. (Let's just put the x86 architecture on a better process, then we'll win!) It was a killer strategy in the 1990s.

Topic.Title: Thirty Days

Message.Msg: "Perhaps the wave which has already started and is building momentum in client virtualization? Yes, I know, wallis, client virtualization means that Intel probably sells more server CPUs, but the ratio isn't promising," [If industry moving towards virtualization and cloud, yes, Intel will sell A LOT more CPUs and the ratio is better than you might think as virtualization/cloud is only in its infancy. As for client side...have you seen the specs and the undeniable performance/power advantage of Silvermont? The advantage will continue with Airmont. And with Intel's process advantage, they will be able to create client's chips cheaper too] " So far I'm looking at the same old same old, strategy-wise." [Where have you been? Have you looked at the specs for Haswell? Intel's strategy is changing big time. They are cramming everything that used be on motherboard and integrating it with the CPU. Look at Haswell, the Voltage regulator, DRAM and GPU are all getting a bigger share of the silicon. semi_equip_junkie commented several times on here that Haswell eliminating as many as seven external third party chips. And if you were paying attention you would have even heard that Intel added switching into their server chips, think about that one! ]

Message.Title: Intel will be chip in all higher end tablets/computers
Message.Msg: Intel teases fanless Haswell Core processor tablet at Computex: It was barely a glimpse, but Intel's pushing the physical limits of its 4th generation Haswell processors. Here on stage, at Computex, we saw one very slender (and as-yet unnamed) tablet that packs the aforementioned processors without the need for fans for cooling. Sure, we've seen fanless Windows 8 tablets with Clover Trail-based hardware, but never with the potency of Intel's Core processor series. Alas, slimline profile (and hybrid skills) aside, that's all we can say for the moment. We'll update if we manage to glean any more details from Intel. from matt smith en gadget web

Message.Title: 2014: Year of the Intel Smartphone
Message.Msg: The real mobility revelation came June 4, when Intel unveiled unreleased devices powered by its 22nm Atom system-on-a-chip (SoC)—a quad-core monster that could deliver a 50 percent improvement in overall performance and 300 percent boost in graphics compared to the current generation of Atom chips, at least according to Intel. The Merrifield SoC also carries an integrated hub for a range of location and environmental sensors, as well as tweaks to device management and security. Merrifield-powered phones won’t hit the market until “Barcelona 2014,” according to Tom Kilroy, the Intel executive making the presentation at Computex, presumably referring to the annual Mobile World Congress conference that takes place in Spain. From slashdot [So that would mean Merrifield smartphones would arrive on Feb 24-27 at the World Mobile Congress in Barcelona. What does this mean? It means that things are about to get very interesting in the very near future. February is not so far off and deals have to be getting made or already have been made due the development and production times. Eight months is so little time that even Wall Street should be able to get their heads around the fact that big change is due in mobility and that 2014 will indeed be the Year of the Intel Smartphone, starting big time in February...]

Topic.Title: Huge XP Replacement Wave on the Way

Message.Msg: Article: "The clock ticks on XP, and a tough transition looms for some agencies" "There are still more XP users than most people think. Net Applications, which tracks users of every OS, says that XP users still make up 37.7 percent of the global market as of May. And although Net Applications doesn’t have separate numbers on the public sector, plenty of those XP users are in government offices, even if the agencies are in the process of upgrading to Windows 7 (most likely) or 8 (less likely). "The only Windows version with a higher install base than XP is Windows 7, at 44.8 percent. Windows 8 users are still stuck in the single digits, at 4.2 percent, behind even Vista at 4.7 percent. Incidentally, Mac OS users account for only 2.9 percent of the global market with others (mostly Linux) holding 5.6 percent. "For individual users, upgrading from XP isn’t a major undertaking, for agencies with a large number of users, it’s a daunting task. As Microsoft notes in a blog post, “If your organization has not started the migration to a modern desktop, you are late.” My comment: The EOL of XP on April 8, 2014 has the potential to create a great deal of stress, especially in government agencies. Microsoft says upgrading an O/S over an enterprise can take 18 to 32 months. From Microsoft Blog: "What does End of Support mean to customers? Simply, it means you should take action to move off of Windows XP. After April 8, 2014, there will be no new security updates, non-security hotfixes, free or paid assisted support options or online technical content updates. Running Windows XP SP3 and Office 2003 in your environment after their end of support date may expose your company to potential risks..." If Y2K can produce panic, why not this?

Topic.Title: Huge XP Replacement Wave on the Way

Message.Msg: I can't understand why so many are still on XP. I could see them having skipped Vista but not Win7. It's going to be quite a wave and it has to start soon. The end of the conversion deadline is just about the same as when we expect to see Merrifield smartphones come out. That's a nice one-two combination. We should see it start to build in Q3 and really pick up some momentum in Q4 before a final flurry in Q1 of 2014. Intel should have tremendous momentum in 2H of this year and continuing into 2014. 2013: Year of the Intel Tablet (tablet sales are doubling each quarter) 2014: Year of the Intel Smartphone (with Merrifield arriving at the World Mobile Congress in February)

Message.Title: World Mobile Congress 2014 in Barcelona
Message.Msg: I'm really starting to look forward to next February's World Mobile Congress and the time leading up to it as we can expect to hear about some major Intel smartphone design wins with Merrifield. It will be interesting to see who breaks from the pack to go with Intel's superior technology, fabrication and manufacturing. I think 2014 might turn out to be the most exciting year in Intel's history. And 2013 is pretty exciting in its own right! I'd say it's just about time for the big firm analysts on Wall Street to have their "OMG, I didn't see this coming!!!" epiphany moment... 2013: Year of the Intel Tablet 2014: Year of the Intel Smartphone

Message.Title: INTEL LOOKING LIKE A GREAT BUY HERE
Message.Msg: Incredible news in the last 2 months. First in May, Intel introduces Silvermont microarchitecture and the specs blew away everyone's expectations. Here's the summary: MERRIFIELD Dual core (1W) at same performance use 2.4x less power than competition (this is in terms of projected future competition when Merrifield comes out). At same power, performs 1.6x the speed of competition. BAY TRAIL Intel's quad core beauties either giving twice the performance at the same power level or 4.3x less power at the same performance. This again is comparing against projected competition when Bay Trail comes out...just incredible. Then earlier this month, Intel unveils Haswell. Again, the specs are just unreal. The most notible Haswell product, which are shipping to end customers right now, are the MacBook Airs. The 11" version offer 70% more battery life (9 hours) and the 13" offer 80% more battery life than the previous (12 hours). Expectations are rising fast now....with this major improvement in battery life, we will see a major PC refresh like we have not seen for a long long time.

Message.Title: Why Intel Shorts Are Looking at Another Tough Week
Message.Msg: 1.) Intel outperformed the Nasdaq all last week. Trend should continue. 2.) Intel continues to enjoy excellent press due to Haswell and Bay Trail. 3.) Futures are currently in the green indicating a good start to tthe week. 4.) Samsung event on Thursday indicates significant risk for shorts and ARM. 5.) The end of the year is shaping up well with promising Intel back-to-school sales, holiday sales and the XP upgrade wave. 6.) The beginning of next year looks like gangbusters with volume 14nm FinFET production coming on board and Merrifield smartphones to hit the market. The roadmap is full.The product pipeline is full. And the improvements are coming in waves...
